verses.text: Hear this, O priests! Pay attention, O house of Israel! Listen, O house of the king! For the judgment is directed to you: for you have become a snare at Mizpah, and a net spread upon Tabor.
verses.comment: The address to priests, people, and king shows the responsibility of religious and civil leaders. The 'snare' and 'net' imply leading others into sin, reminiscent of spiritual shepherds leading the flock astray. This verse brings to mind the church's call to hold leaders accountable, and echoes Jesus' rebukes against corrupt leadership (compare Matt. 23:13).

verses.text: Those who have rebelled have gone deep into slaughter, but I will discipline all of them.
verses.comment: Rebellion leads to self-destruction. The language of 'discipline' emphasizes both justice and mercy—discipline is intended for restoration, which foreshadows divine correction culminating in the New Testament call to repentance.

verses.text: I know Ephraim, and Israel is not hidden from me. For now, O Ephraim, you have turned to prostitution; Israel has become defiled.
verses.comment: 'Prostitution' is frequently used as a metaphor for spiritual unfaithfulness. God's intimate knowledge ('I know... not hidden from me') highlights divine omniscience (Ps. 139:1). Many Church Fathers saw in these warnings a call to faithfulness to the one true faith.

verses.text: Their deeds do not permit them to return to their God, for a spirit of prostitution is within them, and they do not know the LORD.
verses.comment: Persistent sin hardens the heart. 'They do not know the LORD' refers not just to ignorance, but to a broken relationship—important when considering the need for grace and sacramental restoration in restoring that relationship with God.

verses.text: The pride of Israel testifies against him; Israel and Ephraim stumble in their guilt; even Judah stumbles with them.
verses.comment: The unity in sin hints at a corporate dimension of guilt and restoration (see Rom. 3:23). Ultimately, this unity prepares the way for the unity of redemption offered in Christ's one body.

verses.text: With their flocks and herds they go to seek the LORD, but they will not find Him; He has withdrawn from them.
verses.comment: Sacrifices without true repentance are empty. The withdrawal of God echoes similar themes in the prophets and highlights the need for sincere worship, which finds its fullness in Christ's perfect sacrifice.

verses.text: They have betrayed the LORD; for they have borne illegitimate children. Now the new moon will devour them with their fields.
verses.comment: 'Betrayed' points to the seriousness of apostasy. The mention of 'illegitimate children' again uses the metaphor of faithlessness. The 'new moon' (a festival) turning to judgment shows how empty ritual without faith can lead to condemnation (Isa. 1:14).

verses.text: Blow the horn in Gibeah, the trumpet in Ramah. Sound an alarm at Beth-aven: 'Behind you, Benjamin!'
verses.comment: This military language calls to readiness and impending judgment. The mention of various locations can remind the faithful of the importance of remembering historical events in the tradition, pointing forward to the way the Church remembers and proclaims salvation history.

verses.text: Ephraim shall become a desolation in the day of rebuke; among the tribes of Israel I make known what is certain.
verses.comment: 'Desolation in the day of rebuke' refers to the consequences of persistent sin. God's revelation of his judgments brings to mind the prophetic authority and infallibility attached to God's word, a trust later carried into apostolic teaching (Acts 2:42).

verses.text: The princes of Judah have become like those who move boundary stones; upon them I will pour out my wrath like water.
verses.comment: Moving boundary stones violated justice and property laws. Leadership that breaks God’s law invokes particular wrath. Such cautions call believers to fidelity to tradition and doctrine and show the weight of responsibility for those in authority.

verses.text: Ephraim is oppressed, crushed in judgment, because he was determined to follow human commands.
verses.comment: Following mere human commands instead of God's is condemned here and also by Jesus (Matt. 15:9). This distinction underscores the importance of living faith guided by divinely established authority.

verses.text: Therefore I am like a moth to Ephraim, and like rottenness to the house of Judah.
verses.comment: The comparison to 'moth' and 'rottenness' shows a slow, imperceptible judgment. It highlights that sin weakens the community from within, a call to vigilance and regular spiritual renewal.

verses.text: When Ephraim saw his sickness, and Judah his wound, Ephraim went to Assyria and sent to the great king. But he cannot heal you, nor cure your wound.
verses.comment: Seeking help from foreign powers instead of God is futile. True healing comes from God alone. This foreshadows Christ as the divine physician whose authority and healing surpass all worldly rulers.

verses.text: For I will be like a lion to Ephraim, and like a young lion to the house of Judah. I, even I, will tear and go away; I will carry off, and no one will rescue.
verses.comment: God’s power and right to judge are absolute. The lion metaphor emphasizes both severity and majesty. No one can deliver apart from God's mercy, which, according to later revelation, is poured out most abundantly in Christ (John 10:11).

verses.text: I will return to my place until they admit their guilt and seek my face; in their distress they will earnestly seek me.
verses.comment: Divine withdrawal is temporary and aims at conversion and restoration. Repentance is the necessary response, pointing ahead to God’s mercy in Christ, where full reconciliation is made possible through both individual contrition and communal confession.
